data.Title: Georgii Ernesti Stahl, ... Dissertatio epistolica De motu tonico vitali, & hinc dependente motu sanguinis particulari: quâ demonstratur salva circulatione sanguinem & cum eo commeantes humores, ad quamliber corporis partem specialem, prae aliis, copiosius dirigi & propelli posse

data.Titles: Professor of mathematics at University of Rome La Sapienza (1622-27) and University of Padua (1632-1657).
data.Descriptions: Italian mathematician, jurist, astronomer, astrologer, and medical writer. Pupils may have included Placido Titi and Giovanni Battista Seni.
Danish physician, mathematician, theologian best known for discovery of lymphatic system in humans, advancement of theorys of refrigeration anesthesia, father to Thomas Bartholin the Younger.

Transylvanian protestant theologian and philosopher, trained at Leiden under Adrianus Heerebord (Cartesian?) and wrote 24 these on Harveyan theory of the heart. Put primary medical and pastoral focus on healing the heart.

Dutch physician and writer, widely cited as first Dutch physician to defend Harvey's circulatory system. Based in Dordrecht. May have been an experimentalist surgeon (c.f. Steen-stuck (1638)) and invented Dutch neologisms for pancreas, rectum, collarbone, and esophagus.

data.Titles: Journalist, poet, licenser of the press (1660-63)
data.Descriptions: Associated with Archbishop Laud and Oxford Laudians, he ran the weekly intelligencer of the king's party Mercurius Aulicus. Remembered for commendatory poems for comedies of Beaumont, Fletcher, Cartwright and poems of Henry Lawes; friend of Dryden, Katherine Phillps, Henry Vaughan, Henry More, Jeremy Taylor, Thomas Sprat, John Evelyn among others.

Dutch physician at the University of Franeker and physician to Countess Albertine of Nassau, remembered for proving existence of capillary system, developing injection techniques, and first Dutch book on pediatrics. Cartesian interested in disproving spontaneous generation in insects, repeated Francisco Redi's experiments. Corresponded with mystic Antoinette Bourignon; collaborated with Maria Sybilla Merian; teetotaller; follower of Franciscus Sylvius's recommendation of diets copious in tea and coffee; translated works of John Mayow, English physiologist-chemist.

Founder of the first academic chemical laboratory, his students were Swammerdam, Reinier de Graaf, and Niels Stensen; big proponent of iatrochemistry, he is remembered as one of the earliest defenders of the theory of circulation of the blood in the Netherlands. Also major paintings collector.
Little known citizen of Bologna, author of a treatise

Spanish nobleman and physician, described as a moderate Galenist trained at Valladolid and held the chairs of Philosophy, Surgery, and Method; served as physician to Philip IV and Carlos II; one of the first in Spain to describe Harvey's circulation of the blood.

Wrote and lectured extensively against Harvey's theory of blood circulation, known for attempting to secure patronage forcefully and unsuccessfully; twice convicted for libel against Queen Anne's administration; produced sloppy edition of Latin casebooks of Mayerne and treatises on the plague.

Prominent spokesperson for Epicurean ideas in England, admitted a candidate of the College of Physicians; royalist physician to the exiled king Charles II, but remained in London becoming president of the College (1689-91) and senior censor (1698-1706); delivered Harveian orations 1702, 1706; appointed Harbeian librarian 1706. Friend of Thomas Hobes, Francis Prujean, George Ent. Big interest in Stonehenge and in human characters c.f. A Brief Discourse concerning the Different Wits of Men and Natural History of the Passions.

German intellectual from Norden (East Frisia) raised amidst confessional altercations, studied at University of Helmstedt, produced significant studies on blood circulation, sometimes considered a Neo-Aristotelian; forerunner of government statistics

Oxford-trained (graduated 1633) Royal College of Physician member, with dissertation affirmative about Harvey's theory of blood circulation. Christopher Hill calls him the first to defend Harvey's theory in England, preceding Robert Fludd's early defenses published outside of England and George Ent's print defense in 1640s.
Rotterdam-born, physician, became

Student of the académie of Aix-en-Province, where he was given to philsophy and medicine, worked in Paris for a stint before departing for Pisa to teach philosophy in 1628, and becoming chair of Padua in 1640, where he stayed till his death. Generally esteemed as reactionary/conservative towards new ideas, he was in favor of disputatio and dubitatio, combatting Galileo but alligning with Fortunio Liceti. Opposed to Aristotelianism, he attempted to revivie corpuscular philosophy of Anaxagoras.

French philosopher of doubt, of the mind-body split, and of mechanistic corpuscularianism, he is not well known for his work on blood circulation but he seems to have favored a revised version of Harvey's theories and promulgated them through Traité du Monde with his own ideas of the heart as pump

English son of Catholic revolutionary Everard Digby, he was celebrated as an adventurer, amateur experimental scientist of the Royal Society, and anti-Cromwellian loyalist; inventer of the modern wine bottle, he was friends with Descartes and enjoined him to discover the means of prolonging life indefinitely; his interest in circulation is linked to his work on fermentation and alchemy, although not linked to this

English student at Leiden after matriculating at Pembroke College, Cambridge; drawn to puritan theology and presbyterian form of church government; perhaps influenced by Francis Glisson, whose students were beginning to discuss Harvey and blood circulation; then a student of Waleus at Leiden, and one of the first to defend circulation, drawing the ire of James Primrose's animadversions in 1640. Returns to London, publishes Latin vindication of his ideas in attack against Primrose. Elected to College of Physicians in 1643; greatly admired by Richard Baxter for his piety and preaching, wrote controversial literature regarding ban against free admission to the Lord's supper.

Dutch philosopher and professor of medicine at University of Utrecth from 1638 onwards; he studied at Franeker, Groningen, Leiden, and Montpellier and Padua. Vocal proponent of Cartesianism, corresponded frequently with Descartes.

English-born son of Belgian immigrants, became fellow of Royal College of Physicians after graduating from Sidney Sussex Cambridge and Padua; also elected to Royal Society (1663). Met Harvey in Venice after graduating Padua and was close friend; credited with convincing Harvey to release de Generatione Animalium, edited and published by Ent. His Apologia combined Harvey's theories on circulation with John Mayow's theories on innate heat and respiration to discuss the nervous system -- more inclined to use writers now considered occult whom Harvey dismissed. Also studied anatomy, fossilized wood, Chruch unity.

Best known as an occult philosopher, he exchanged with Kepler, was on good terms with Sir William Paddy, may have been influenced by Matthew Gwienne's Galeno-Paracelsian reconciliations; graduated from Christ Church, Oxford, made repeated attempts to enter College of Physicians but was challenged because of contempt for traditional medical authorities; one of the first to support in print the theory of circulation; allegations that he may have influenced Harvey's discovery, but that depends on how you date the discovery.

Nephew of Giambattatista Folli, city physician of Venice, Cecilio studied at Padua under Johannes Wesling and became professor of anatomy in Venice (1636) before later serving as chairman of the Venetian Medical and Surgical College; he had an anatomy theater built on Campo San Giacomo dall'Orio. His 1639 dissertation on the foramen oval in the heart led him to misconclude that Harvey's theory of the septum and deny circulation. His anatomies of the ear were the most precise to date and dedicated to Thomas Bartholin.
Student of polymath Bohemian polymath Johannes Marcus Marci
